comment: Wish I would of tasted it prior.... Heavy hay like flavor great body other than that did not enjoy haven't touched it in almost 8months, attempted it again the other night.... Nope not for me

It's a hodgepodge of scents and flavors, kind of fun to figure out! Toasted marshmallows, fresh cut dandelions, and charred maple wood on the nose.  The palate picks up walnut, dried cherries, and frothy seafoam. Awfully unique in the vast world of bourbon whiskey!
The description in Distiller says sweet, but I found it to be earthy, almost smokey. Good.

Several months ago, I tried a pour of batch #5 in an establishment in downtown Denver.  Yesterday, i did the local Laws distillery tour.  I have to say that i am very impressed with this bourbon in many ways.  The no compromise approach they use is something I have never seen in this industry.  Their process is perhaps 95% transparent.  They will tell you the mash bill and explain the process to the point of only keeping the wart boiling  temperatures and the actual distillation temperatures a secret. They cut no corners to craft the product they produce.  
    
    Here are my tasting notes:
    
    Nose: it has a nice alcoholic fuminess and a very pleasant smell.  I detect some pepper and leather and a tiny bit of spiciness from the rye.  As the glass is swirled, it is very noticeable  that the glycerine content is high in this spirit.  There is a very dark caramel color for it only being 3 years old. 
    
    Taste: Peach, apricot, butterscotch, vanilla, a tiny bit of chocolate.  Rolling into the mid palate and finish, I detect a good deal of distilled grape such as sherry flavors. Perhaps if i were to have a critique of the profile, i would say this "sherry" flavor is a little too predominant.  However, there are lots of bold but plesant flavors and an incredible amount  of complexity for a 3 year old bourbon.  
    
    Finish: this spirit has a nice burn but it is not excessive.  The finish lasts a very long time.  There is a very nice syrupy-ness without being too thick.
    
    Overall, I have to say that this is a VERY good spirit, especially keeping in mind that it is only 3 years old.  Its not perfectly rounded, but I believe this will come as they release older age statements in the coming years. I think it could use a little more oak and char to round out the  palate.   I predict in the future that this will be one of those bourbons that are impossible to find and will trade on the secondary market for exponentially more than MSRP.
    
    Unfortunately, since they are a new company, this product is not readily available  in many areas.  I will call it Colorado's best kept bourbon secret.  If you get to this state, search out a liquor store and pick up a bottle.  
    
    Since they have been on the market now for 4 years, they have started releasing expiramentals. at the distillery, they had two wheat whiskeys that can be found in some stores.  the "a" is 100% wheat and the "b" is a wheat with 5% malted barley. Both are very good spirits.  They allowed us to try a Cask Strength  single barrel bourbon.  I was so impressed with this one that I purchased a bottle to take home.  A few months ago, they released a "bottled in bond" variety.  Unfortunately, they were sold out and I was unable to try this one.  i will be looking for it the next time its released.....
Earthy and substantial. Reminds me of a fresh loaf of bread with a hint of cinnamon.
Sweet nose with a slight bite at the end...
Too rich for me but excellent for what it is.
Well rounded whiskey for being so young.  Not too hot and surprisingly has great flavor.

Pretty good bourbon.  Went down very smooth with three ice cubes in a rocks glass.  It kept tasting like more, so I finished the bottle. 
  
   Note:  I had a 125ml sampler bottle
Purchased from liquor and wine executive concierge in Denver. Pretty solid whiskey
Quality four grain bourbon coming outta Colorado!

Not sure why this is rated so low. A solid bourbon that I always keep in my rotation. heavy caramel and tobacco notes with a bold and unapologetic finish. Like the guy that pulls his welding truck into the last liquor store parking space in front of your wannabe monster truck. Frankly, I give this a solid "90".

Not quite as good as I remember, but still really good for a four grain. It does taste a smidge young, but the flavors are very nice. If they release this with a longer age statement it will be something special.
Less burn than their wheat. Complex flavor.

It's definitely young. Definitely overpriced. It could be good if it was aged another 4-6 years. It could probably be really good. The nose almost smells like tequila, but it doesn't taste like tequila. Bizarre.

Hats off to Amanda Schuster she nailed the review on this one. Spice, fruit, cherry, vanilla, caramel, malt and leather. I like it, very interesting dram, unique like Balcones is but not as artificial or one noted. Impressive for a young dram. Wasn't impressed by its Secale Rye brother but this is a 4.

Nose - orange zest, almond, hints of vanilla and caramel.
Palate - black tea, pepper, clove...long and dry.
Rye forward, some heat, some complexity and roundness after and smooth finish
Maybe on equal terms with some young KY bourbons, but it should be priced accordingly. I’ll take a $10 young KY bourbon over this higher priced CO one. Maybe with age, it will be fantastic.
Fun on the front, good body.  Finishes a little harsh.  Aged only 3 years, most likely contributes to that.

Excellent stuff! Tried the bonded bourbon at the distillery and bought a bottle of the farmers select(47.5 abv) to take home. The wheat and barley together play really well against the corn and rye. Not exactly sure what or how they did it but this is interesting stuff, which garners a higher rating than that given by the reviewer.
A bit of a rye bite. Too much for me without ice/water
Smoother than your average bourbon, but not as complex as I would have liked. Try it again with water/ice as I was told it would bring out more vanilla and caramel flavors.

Tasted at NWB. 12/19/18
Young. Strong up front with flavorful finish.

Smell sour 
Upfront Bitter Spicy
Slow Burn
Chalky and tastes like carob.  Won’t do it again.

I’m a Colorado native, love everything CO.  That being said I hate this bourbon.  Super hot, too young and inconsistent.  I’ve had 2 $70 bottles gifted to me and I can’t even drink them.  Spend your money on some cheaper KY bourbon and thank me later.
Complex and interesting but a little spicy for me. I guess I prefer a little more traditional Bourbon profile
smooth but didn't love the flavor. was a little disappointed really. I'll be trying this again. I had it right after Bookers which probably threw me off.

Batch 15
This begins like a wheater, very soft, honey and caramel.  Mid brings some tobacco and pepper.  Finish.... is harsh, tastes like young oak.  Aging another 4-6 years would probably make an amazing whiskey. As it is bottled, it isn't.

What better way to kill an hour at the Denver airport than to try a local Colorado craft distillery?  With craft Americans, I’ve learned they fall into three categories:
1) tried and tested must haves: the likes of Del Bac Dorado, McKenzie and High West.  
2) on the fence, depends on product and batch: High West, Westland, Balcones , Westward, New Southern Distillery, St George 
3) try at bar: countless to list 

This one falls in (3).  I’m glad I’ve tried a local CO product, but not worth the asking price of $80-100USD.  Nose is mild—almost like sourdough bread.  You get more action in the palette—rye being the foremost.  

Overall, interesting pour—try at a bar to experiment or experience.
Sweet corn and vanilla and molasses on the nose. Mostly rye on the tongue, dark or ripe fruit. Nice complexity from the four grains. Water opens up the fruit flavors more. Complexity is nice.
Nose is great, caramel sauce, woody, malty, smoldering. Taste is balanced, apricot, chess pie, a little drying, butterscotch. Shorter finish, smooth down the throat
Delicious and so smooth. Really clear, as well. Favorite CO whiskey.

A really complex and tasty bourbon. It’s dramatically different than most bourbon profiles and it’s a really interesting twist. 

Nose - orange peel, black tea, honey, and black pepper, and a bit of rye and baking spices
Taste - spicy orange at first, with some soft honey sweetness, a bit of black tea adds complexity
Finish - the honey fades quickly and the rye spice lingers, there’s enough heat to get your attention

The bottle I actual had was the bottle in bond four grain, but unfortunately Distiller doesn't have it in their archive and I wasn't able to take a picture of the bottle!

I will first say that i was a Big fan of the E.H. Taylor four grain bourbon and since I won't pay $700 for secondary prices i though I would try this AD Laws bottle at the Whiskey House in San Diego. Overall I will say this is a pretty darn good substitution and all the grains mingle very well with each other. I like the four grain because it isn't your typical bourbon profile so if you like whiskey that a little different i would recommend this one.
Very different, fruity nose. Fruity and caramel flavor. Smooth finish with just a little spice. Not bad, but not my style.
Oily start, lots of smoke and flavor in the mid. Ends with a barbecue flavor, smoked wood and oily coat. Good with food
Complex and smokey. Grainy flavors. Interesting and different

It’s hot and a little spicy. But it’s a bourbon that reminds you that you’re drinking whiskey. It’s interesting and dynamic. I love bourbons that stand out, just as much as I love calm and relaxed ones.

One of the most interesting noses to a whiskey I’ve ever experienced. A wide variety of fruit and earth. The taste starts with vanilla and quickly mellows into some tea, butterscotch, and spicy rye before ending with a bit of tobacco.

Nose - Vanilla / wet hay / honey/  orange/ baking spice
Taste - cinnamon  / Oak
Finish - vanilla pretty quick

Lots going on in the bourbon. I keep thinking a taste more but cant put my finger on it.
Wow I’m no bourbon expert but this 4 grain does it for me, that wheat grassy cereal with a cigar finish makes this one super drinkable. I find it one I want to drink frequently.
One of my first favorites. Excited to try the 6-year BiB.
Aromatic in the glass. Mild at the start, peppery middle and clean finish.
